elephant: Elephants trucks have 40,000 muscles and can delicately pick up a single blade of grass or rip branches off trees
Elephants are the largest land mammals on Earth.
Elephants are incredibly intelligent and can remember people, places, and experiences for many years — showing remarkable long-term memory.
Elephants drink over 200 liters of water a day and use their tusks to dig for water.
Elephants communicate with low-frequency sounds and vibrations that can travel miles.
octopus: Octopus have three hearts and blue blood
Under stress, octopuses sometimes detach an arm, which can keep moving for up to an hour.
giraffe: Giraffe sleep only a few minutes at a time (often totaling under 2 hours a day)
Giraffes are the tallest land animals in the world (14-19ft).
Giraffes spotted coat patterns are unique to each individual — like fingerprints.
Giraffes spots help with camouflage and act as thermal windows to help cool the body.
Giraffes use necking — neck-to-neck combat — to establish dominance.
dog: Dogs have an amazing sense of smell — much stronger than humans, which is why they are used in tracking and detection roles.
Dogs were one of the first animals domesticated by humans, living with people for thousands of years.
Dogs can hear sounds at frequencies far beyond human range, making their hearing extremely sensitive.
There are hundreds of dog breeds, each with unique traits and skills.
Some dogs can understand over 100 words and commands with proper training.
cat: Cats sleep a lot — about 70% of their lives — making them expert nappers!
Cats have 32 muscles that control their ears, allowing incredibly precise movement.
Cats can make over 100 different vocal sounds, while dogs make about 10.
A group of kittens is called a ‘kindle.’
Cats have whiskers on the backs of their front legs as well as their face!
lion: Lions are the only big cats that live in social groups, which are called prides.
A lion’s roar can be heard up to 5 miles (about 8 kilometers) away.
Female lions (lionesses) are the primary hunters in the pride.
Male lions’ manes vary in color and size, and darker manes are associated with stronger males.
Lions spend up to 20 hours a day resting.
tiger: Tigers are the largest members of the cat family.
Even if a tiger's fur is shaved, its skin retains the same striped pattern.
A tiger’s striped pattern is unique, like a human fingerprint.
Tigers mark territory using scent and scratch marks.
Tiger cubs learn to hunt by watching their mothers.
Tigers can swim well and often enjoy water — unlike many other cats.
kangaroo: Kangaroos are surprisingly strong swimmers, paddling with their hind legs and steering with their tail.
The red kangaroo is the largest, standing over 6 feet tall and weighing up to about 200 pounds.
Kangaroos generally cannot hop backward because their powerful hind legs and long tail are built for forward movement.
squirrel: Squirrels can leap about six feet in a single bound and survive falls from roughly 100 feet by using their tail for balance and as a parachute.
Squirrels often fake-bury nuts to deceive thieves, digging and covering empty holes while keeping the nut to hide elsewhere.
They can sniff out food buried under a foot of snow, combining scent with memory of landmarks.
One squirrel may bury thousands of nuts each year across many spots (scatter-hoarding) to improve the odds of finding some later.
hippo: A hippo’s closest living relatives are whales, dolphins, and porpoises, sharing a semi-aquatic ancestor from ~55 million years ago.
Despite their bulk, hippos can sprint up to about 22 mph over short distances—faster than a human.
Adult hippos eat roughly 80–110 pounds of grass nightly, grazing for hours and traveling miles to feed.
Hippos can’t swim; they walk or run along riverbeds and can hold their breath for around five minutes.
Hippos secrete a reddish “blood sweat” that acts as sunscreen, antibiotic, and cooling layer.
koala: Koalas have fingerprints almost identical to humans, making them hard to tell apart even under a microscope.
Koalas have two opposable thumbs on each front paw for an incredibly strong grip on trees.
A koala’s thick, padded tail acts like a built-in cushion so they can sit in trees for hours.
The name “koala” comes from an Aboriginal word meaning “no drink,” since they get most moisture from eucalyptus leaves.
panda: Pandas munch bamboo for 12+ hours a day, using a pseudo-thumb to grip it, and poop frequently because digestion is inefficient.
About 99% of a panda’s diet is bamboo, so they eat roughly 26–83 pounds daily to get enough nutrients.
Despite their bulk, pandas are agile in trees and water, and can cross rivers in the wild.
Instead of hibernating, pandas move to lower elevations for warmer winter temperatures.
zebra: No two zebras share the same stripe pattern—like human fingerprints—which helps them recognize one another.
Their stripes can confuse predators and even deter biting flies, acting as natural pest control.
Zebras are actually black animals with white stripes, not the other way around.
They communicate with barks, brays, and expressive facial cues.
Zebras are fast and athletic, reaching 40+ mph to escape predators.
bear: Bears are highly intelligent—capable of problem solving, complex vocal communication, and even basic tool use.
Their sense of smell is extraordinarily strong, detecting food, mates, or threats from miles away—stronger than a bloodhound.
Most bears are omnivores; exceptions include the carnivorous polar bear and the panda bear, which eats almost exclusively bamboo.
Sun bears have exceptionally long tongues, reaching up to about 9.8 inches to extract insects and honey.
There are eight bear species: North American black bear, brown bear, polar bear, Asiatic black bear, Andean bear, panda bear, sloth bear, and sun bear.
wolf: A wolf’s sense of smell is roughly 100 times stronger than a human’s, and they hear exceptionally well.
Wolves sit at the top of their food chain; humans are their primary predator.
They typically hunt large prey like deer or moose using endurance and teamwork, but will also take smaller animals.
Howls carry long distances (up to ~10 miles) to coordinate the pack and mark territory, along with body language and scent.
Wolves are the largest wild canids, capable of traveling 12+ miles in a day and sprinting around 37–43 mph.
